repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Transport Air Quality Management
            for Mexico City, Highway Rehabilitation and Safety, and
            Infrastructure Privatization Technical Assistance Projects

abstracts.cdata!:
This audit concurs with the satisfactory
            ratings of project outcomes by the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR), regarding the Transport Air Quality Management
            in Mexico City (TAQMP), Highway Rehabilitation and Safety
            (HRSP), and the Infrastructure Privatization Technical
            Assistance (IPTAP) Projects, and their likely
            sustainability, concurring largely with the ICR ratings of
            substantial institutional development impacts, except in the
            case of the HRSP, which rates same as modest. The three
            projects addressed different, but important dimensions of
            Mexico's transport sector, and, all three projects
            largely achieved their objectives, despite significant
            initial implementation problems in the case of the air
            quality, and the highway projects. Three lessons emerge from
            these operations. First, much progress can be achieved in
            reducing the impact of road transport on air quality,
            through a combination of public and private sector measures,
            starting with an adequate system of incentives, put in place
            by federal, and state governments. Second, allocation of
            highway maintenance funding optimizes outcome, when
            preference is given to routine, and periodic maintenance
            over rehabilitation, but network condition is bound to
            deteriorate if funding for rehabilitation is not made
            available. Third, regarding infrastructure privatization
            ,and in order to gain public acceptance, requires as
            necessary (but not always sufficient) conditions, a
            transparent privatization process, compliance with
            commitments by private operators, and government provision
            of social protection to users of non-commercial services,
            and to staff made redundant.

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Infrastructure Privatization
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The ratings show satisfactory outcomes,
            and likely sustainability. However, and despite a
            satisfactory appraisal, the lack of understanding during
            appraisal, of the precise collaborative roles of the
            Inter-ministerial Commission for Privatization, and sector
            ministries, complicated project design, since the assumption
            of Government commitments to the project, under-estimated
            the potential opposition to privatization from state
            enterprises, unions, and political elements, aggravated by
            over-estimating incentives in establishing independent
            regulatory bodies for the newly privatized companies. Thus
            lessons convey the need to ensure political commitment to
            privatization during project preparation, and, to understand
            the precise implications of its privatization process. And,
            particularly in light of imperfect markets, where monopolies
            still persist, regulatory strengthening should be
            established prior to privatization itself.

18225742.theme: State-owned enterprise restructuring and privatization,Regulation and competition policy

repnme.cdata!:
Mexico - Infrastructure Privatization
            Technical Assistance Project

abstracts.cdata!:
The Infrastructure Privatization
            Technical Assistance Project aims to: 1) help Government
            choose structural options for sector reform; 2) develop a
            sound legal and regulatory framework in support of
            privatization; 3) reduce, and if possible, eliminate
            constraints to privatization in sectors covered by the loan;
            and 4) provide support to the privatization preparation
            process. Project activities will include: 1) hiring
            consultants to assist in the analysis of sector structure,
            the development of strategic options, policies and
            regulations; 2) hiring consultants to design and participate
            in the privatization process; 3) financing participation in
            training programs and other human resource development
            activities; and 4) procurement of necessary software,
            hardware and related equipment.
